abstract.p: Letter from Chloe Bordewich, a fifth grader, commenting on Oct 10 article, says schoolchildren should not be given so much homework that they cannot get a good night's sleep or have time to practice an instrument; drawing

block.p: I am a fifth-grade student in Dutchess County, New York. Regarding your Oct. 10 front-page article about the school board that limited homework in Piscataway, N.J., I think that having regular homework until 10:45 p.m. and then having to practice an instrument is terrible. But I also think that the school board went a little too far when it prohibited teachers from grading homework. What is the point of homework if it isn't corrected?

I am a fifth-grade student in Dutchess County, New York. Regarding your Oct. 10 front-page article about the school board that limited homework in Piscataway, N.J., I think that having regular homework until 10:45 p.m. and then having to practice an instrument is terrible. But I also think that the school board went a little too far when it prohibited teachers from grading homework. What is the point of homework if it isn't corrected?

At my public school in Red Hook, the homework policy is: third grade, 30 minutes; fourth grade, 40 minutes; fifth grade, 50 minutes; and so on. That is a better policy because it is just enough to reinforce the concepts learned in school, but not so much that it makes us have to choose between getting a good night's sleep and practicing our instruments, in my case the trumpet.
CHLOE BORDEWICH Red Hook, N.Y., Oct. 10, 2000
